As [Pagoda winds down its services](https://docs.near.org/blog/2024-08-13-pagoda-services), there is a need to transition the management and development of the Kit Wallet Indexer to a capable service provider.", "timeline": {"status": "ACCEPTING_SUBMISSIONS"}, "description": "## Overview\\\\n\\\\nKit Wallet Indexer API is an undocumented but widely used lightweight indexer that helps to find user\\\\u{2019}s FTs, NFTs, and accounts by public key, that builds off of [NEAR Lake Framework](https://docs.near.org/concepts/advanced/near-lake-framework) (which also has an RFP). As [Pagoda winds down its services](https://docs.near.org/blog/2024-08-13-pagoda-services), there is a need to transition the management and development of the Kit Wallet Indexer to a capable service provider. The transition aims to ensure uninterrupted service of this vital data infrastructure, which is essential for various stakeholders in the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\n* Indexer Endpoints API: [https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/indexer.js](https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/indexer.js)\\\\n* Indexer Endpoints Code: [https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js](https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js)\\\\n\\\\n**Current live endpoints**\\\\n\\\\n* Mainnet [https://api.kitwallet.app/](https://api.kitwallet.app/) (currently hosted on AWS)\\\\n* Testnet [https://testnet-api.kitwallet.app/](https://testnet-api.kitwallet.app/)\\\\n\\\\n## Requirements\\\\n\\\\n**Include the following endpoints on mainnet and testnet:**\\\\n\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/publicKey/:publicKey/accounts\\\\\\', findAccountsByPublicKey);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/staking-deposits/:accountId\\\\\\', findStakingDeposits);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/activity\\\\\\', findAccountActivity);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/callReceivers\\\\\\', findReceivers);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyTokens\\\\\\', findLikelyTokens);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyNFTs\\\\\\', findLikelyNFTs);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyTokensFromBlock\\\\\\', findLikelyTokensFromBlock);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyNFTsFromBlock\\\\\\', findLikelyNFTsFromBlock);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/stakingPools\\\\\\', findStakingPools);\\\\n\\\\n**An instance of PostgresSQL, copy of databases, and implemented as follows:**\\\\nhttps://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js#L11\\\\n\\\\n## Usage \\\\n\\\\nThe graph below indicates the most recent usage for the past months KitWallet LB requests: ~350K per day (average response time is less than 0.14 seconds, but there are spikes of 50 seconds or more currently)\\\\n\\\\n![alt_text](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a5b10c0a-7aba-4d44-bd33-7a5ae05e42e1 \\\\\\\"image_tooltip\\\\\\\")\\\\n\\\\n![alt_text](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7c4fc10a-8b12-48be-be65-c1b01336b7d5 \\\\\\\"image_tooltip\\\\\\\")\\\\n\\\\n_Note: the majority of endpoint usage, [FastNear](https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs) already supports_\\\\n\\\\nThis Kit Wallet Indexer API is undocumented and not officially supported.  Because of this, many wallets that are more NEAR \\\\u{201c}native\\\\u{201d} have already switched to other solutions like [FastNEAR](https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs).  But there are still many [non-custodial](https://github.com/near/wallet-selector) and exchange wallets that depend on the Kit Wallet Indexer service or that we are still confirming their usage. \\\\n\\\\nWe do not have data available which NEAR ecosystem projects are currently using Kit Wallet Indexer but these should include wallets and exchanges and any projects that need to quickly query different token balances.\\\\n\\\\nEcosystem projects that have already  transitioned off of Kit Wallet to better-maintained services include [Nightly](https://nightly.app/), [Meteor Wallet](https://wallet.meteorwallet.app/), MyNEARWallet, NEAR Mobile Wallet, and [Bitte/Mintbase Wallet](wallet.bitte.ai).\\\\n\\\\n#### Monitoring, Alerting, Reporting\\\\n\\\\n* \\\\u{200b}\\\\u{200b}Real-time monitoring of system health and performance with public forward facing status page\\\\n* Alerts for data inconsistencies or indexing delays and public channel & direct communication with major stakeholders using service\\\\n* Internal Dashboard for visualizing system metrics\\\\n* Weekly progress reports during the transition phase to Infrastructure committee asynchronous \\\\n* Quarterly performance and usage reports\\\\n\\\\n#### Documentation\\\\n\\\\n**As part of this transition, maintenance, and proposals, please include;**\\\\n\\\\n* Comprehensive system architecture documentation\\\\n* API documentation including usage examples (mentioning the service will be deprecated and linked to alternative solutions like _[FastNear](https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs) _) \\\\n* User guide for common queries and use cases.\\\\n\\\\n### Transition Steps for selected vendor\\\\n\\\\n1. Review and understand the current Kit Wallet Indexer API infrastructure (including accompanying infra like NEAR Lake) and processes.\\\\n2. Include detailed transition plan,in your milestones\\\\n3. Set up necessary access and permissions for the new team.\\\\n4. Conduct knowledge transfer sessions with the current Pagoda team.\\\\n5. Implement and test any necessary changes or improvements to the infrastructure.\\\\n6. Perform thorough testing to ensure data integrity and system performance.\\\\n7. Update all relevant documentation.\\\\n8. Gradually transition operational responsibilities.\\\\n9. Establish new support channels and processes.\\\\n10. Conduct a final review and handover with the Infrastructure Committee.\\\\n11. Conduct official communications on your channels and with the NEAR Developer ecosystems and relevant stakeholders\\\\n12. As part of this RFP and based on current usage, the goal is to provide this as a public good. Part of this transition strategy may include pushing users to alternatives like FastNEAR API. \\\\n13. Estimated transition time, not taking into account any KYC or KYB blockers, is 1 week.  \\\\n\\\\n### Service Level Agreements\\\\n\\\\n1. **Availability**\\\\n    * **Uptime Guarantee**: 99.0% monthly uptime\\\\n    * **Downtime Allowance**: Up to 0.1% of downtime per month\\\\n2. **Performance**:\\\\n    * *This should be tracked internally and shared with Infrastructure Committee (IC)*\\\\n    * **Response Time**:\\\\n        * Better or in line with existing response time.\\\\n    * **Rate Limiting**:\\\\n        * Please outline your rate limiting plan to continue to support Kit Wallet as a public good, if applicable. \\\\n3. **Support**\\\\n* **Support Availability**: Community-based support only (e.g., through forums, GitHub issues, or a developer community Slack/Telegram/Discord channel)\\\\n* **Response Time**: No guaranteed response time, but best-effort responses within 24-48 hours. A single point of contact for urgent issues.\\\\n4. **Data Integrity**\\\\n* **Data Consistency**: \\\\n    * Ensure that there is data validation in place (to show proper information). \\\\n    * Proper backup of data is maintained and the data is up to date. \\\\n5. **Updates and Changes**\\\\n* **Notice for Breaking Changes**: At least 7 days\\\\\\' notice for any breaking changes in the API or infrastructure\\\\n* **Versioning**: Ensure that the new API versions will be backward-compatible wherever possible.\\\\n* Maintenance - Proper updates to the community and stakeholders about any major maintenance which could impact the service, experience and uptime of the API adversely. \\\\n6. **Limitations**\\\\n    * **No SLA Credits**: No financial credits or compensation for outages or performance issues for free public good services. \\\\n    * **Fair Use Policy**: Provide Explicit statements about the intended use for development and the prohibition of production workloads\\\\n7. **Termination Rights**: The right to suspend or terminate the service for users who exceed fair use or misuse the service. IC must be informed about these.\\\\n8. **Failure to Perform:** If Kit Wallet maintenance falls below the performance aforementioned benchmarks, the Infrastructure Committee has the right to transition this public good to another vendor. The current maintainer will be required to facilitate the transition. \\\\n\\\\n### Budget Guidelines\\\\n\\\\n* **Budget**: Proposals should outline a **detailed budget**. A clear breakdown of costs, including development, testing, documentation, maintenance & support, infrastructure, 3rd party services and external API costs. Maintenance cost should be calculated accurately based on provided usage information and existing software costs. Being able to properly assess a budget based on usage is a major factor for qualifying legitimate vendors.\\\\n* **Milestones**: Please highlight the details of the various milestones that are included in your development plan and relevant budgets attached to each milestone. Any metrics around success of the milestone (acceptance criterion) should also be included. Milestone examples include upon signing of agreement, upon official transition, 6 month billing period, 12 month billing period, \\\\u{2026} and so forth. \\\\n* **Contingency**: Include a contingency plan for potential overruns or unexpected expenses. In the event that expense for providing free or a public good to the NEAR ecosystem, there should be a clear policy to report expenses incurred by NEAR usage to cover additional costs and prove that costs exceeded previous budgets. \\\\n\\\\n### Required Experience\\\\n\\\\n* **Experience:** Proven experience in big data processing, cloud infrastructure management, and blockchain data indexing, preferably within the blockchain or fintech sectors. Experience working with NEAR Protocol is a plus.\\\\n* **Portfolio:** Examples of previous work and case studies demonstrating success in similar projects.\\\\n* **Team:** A skilled team comprising developers, data engineers, and support staff with relevant experience.\\\\n* **Relevant Business:** Demonstrate that your team has an existing business that would motivate you to continue building and maintaining this infrastructure\\\\n\\\\n## Resources\\\\n\\\\n**Alternatives to Kit Wallet;**\\\\n\\\\n* Fast NEAR API Server: [https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs](https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs) (hosted free alternative)\\\\n* Pagoda enhanced api: [https://console.pagoda.co/apis?tab=enhancedApi#/](https://console.pagoda.co/apis?tab=enhancedApi#/) \\\\n* NEARBlocks api: [https://api.nearblocks.io/v1/account/rektdegen.near/inventory](https://api.nearblocks.io/v1/account/rektdegen.near/inventory) \\\\n* HERE Wallet ZMQ Indexer [https://github.com/here-wallet/near-zmq-indexer](https://github.com/here-wallet/near-zmq-indexer)  \\\\n* [Mintbase Indexer](https://docs.mintbase.xyz/dev/mintbase-graph) [https://github.com/here-wallet/near-zmq-indexer](https://github.com/here-wallet/near-zmq-indexer) \\\\n\\\\n**Support;** \\\\n\\\\n* NEAR Indexer Working Group [https://nearbuilders.com/tg-data](https://nearbuilders.com/tg-data) \\\\n\\\\n**Kit Wallet Resources;**\\\\n\\\\n* [https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper](https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper)\\\\n* Indexer Endpoints API: [https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/indexer.js](https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/indexer.js)\\\\n* Indexer Endpoints Code: [https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js](https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js)\\\\n\\\\n**Past Proposals;**\\\\n\\\\n* HERE Wallet [https://gov.near.org/t/proposal-develop-public-near-indexer-from-here-wallet-team-compatible-with-kitwallet-api/37307](https://gov.near.org/t/proposal-develop-public-near-indexer-from-here-wallet-team-compatible-with-kitwallet-api/37307)\\\\n\\\\n## Process\\\\n\\\\n**[Proposal Process](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1F7iAT9tWngik9JPS_GadCCEB5nZtA2AiL2yWZoBGMFM/pub)**\\\\n\\\\nYou should submit a proposal in response to this RFP on the Infrastructure Committee Portal. [Here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TVvPXPJhZfaFwfA2UMW6c3pO2kis45SJ1Np1XOkkhnA/edit?usp=sharing) is a standard (+ [markup](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UZRfOE1JAOhsnSmp-RmL2hY7KPJbpBImKZVvPV4YJmA/edit?usp=sharing)) template you can use as a starting point. \\\\n\\\\nMarketing materials, presentations, and images can be attached as needed as external links. An easy way to do this is to start a discussion under the Proposals category on the Infrastructure Working Group GitHub repository [here](https://github.com/near/Infrastructure-Working-Group/discussions/categories/proposals), publish, then edit and copy the links generated to the files you uploaded.\\\\n\\\\n#### Proposal Submission Dates\\\\n\\\\nThe deadline for proposal submission is **Tuesday, October 15th** (giving applicants approximately three weeks), with a Q&A period on the proposal itself. We will accept submissions after this date, however, on-time proposals will take priority.\\\\n\\\\n### Selection Process\\\\n\\\\nAfter reviewing the proposals, the committee will vote on the best one. Generally, this process takes two working weeks to complete and will be discussed and voted on at the regular bi-weekly meeting.\\\\n\\\\n#### Voting Dates\\\\n\\\\nThe estimate for voting completion is **two weeks** after the proposal submission date.\\\\n\\\\n### Transition Process\\\\n\\\\nThe estimated transition time is one week, not considering any KYC or KYB blockers.  \\\\n\\\\n### Funding Process\\\\n\\\\nThe Infrastructure Committee governs funding with assistance from the NEAR Foundation. If selected, your proposal enters the funding pipeline. You are required to:\\\\n\\\\n* Complete the KYC/B process conducted by the NEAR Foundation, including verification by IDVerify.\\\\n* Sign a legal agreement regarding the work as outlined in the proposal conducted by the NEAR Foundation.\\\\n* Submit an invoice to NEAR Foundation Finance outlining how you want funds disbursed, to what wallets or banks, and in the agreed-upon amounts.\\\\n* Complete a test transaction to verify target wallets (when requesting funds in cryptocurrency).\\\\n\\\\n#### Funding Dates\\\\n\\\\nThe funding process is generally completed in one working week if the proposal does not require clarifications in the budget, work approach, legal agreement, or invoicing terms.\\\\n\\\\n## Communication\\\\n\\\\nPlease direct all communications to the thread where the RFP started beneath the submitted proposal. Please direct confidential or sensitive communications to the Telegram group set up between the committee and the organization/entity/team. If you don\\\\\\'t have a private Telegram group between your team and the Infrastructure Committee, please request one in this thread.\\\\n\\\\n", "rfp_body_version": "V0", "submission_deadline": "1728950400000000000"}, "labels": ["Indexers"]}

{"id": 28, "body": {"name": "Aurora Labs: NEAR Lake", "summary": "Aurora Labs proposes to take over the NEAR Lake service for further maintenance and development.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REVIEW", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "linked_rfp": 3, "supervisor": null, "description": "## Organization\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\u{2019}s contact information\\\\n\\\\nAlex Shevchenko ([alex.shevchenko@aurora.dev](alex.shevchenko@aurora.dev)) - Aurora Labs CEO\\\\n\\\\n### Project DRIs\\\\n\\\\nDimitar Petkov ([dimitar.petkov@aurora.dev](dimitar.petkov@aurora.dev))\\\\nDmitry Strokov ([dmitry.strokov@aurora.dev](dimitar.petkov@aurora.dev))\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n\\\\n48 people\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the engineering team\\\\n\\\\n23 people\\\\n\\\\n## Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n### Examples of relevant experience with NEAR blockchain\\\\n\\\\nAurora Labs\\\\u{2019} engineering team has developed significant expertise in indexing, storing, and distributing blockchain data to meet the demands of internal infrastructure. Over the past two and a half years, the focus has been on building and refining a robust data pipeline designed to deliver maximum speed, high availability, fault tolerance, and efficient global data access.\\\\n\\\\nTo support these capabilities, the team includes engineers with experience in the relevant parts of the nearcore codebase, which enables the maintenance and customization of an in-house version of the NEAR Indexer using the NEAR Indexer Framework. This specialized knowledge has been instrumental in operating instances of nearcores and NEAR Indexers, ensuring that Aurora RPC services consistently achieve high availability and performance.\\\\n\\\\nThe entire infrastructure is continuously monitored and backed-up to maintain optimal performance and reliability across various regions worldwide, aligning with the company\\\\\\'s commitment to delivering resilient and responsive blockchain services.\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\n\\\\nThe proposed solution involves adopting the current setup for NEAR Lake from the Pagoda team, with a focus on ensuring reliability and high availability, eliminating potential vulnerabilities, and establishing comprehensive monitoring. The approach includes deploying new or additional indexer instances if necessary to meet failover/latency demands.\\\\n\\\\nAdditionally, there is a plan to potentially integrate the process of writing to NEAR Lake into the existing infrastructure pipeline in the future, aiming to reduce operational costs by reusing data from the indexers for both internal needs of Aurora infrastructure and the needs of NEAR Lake.\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n1. Conduct knowledge transfer sessions with the Pagoda team\\\\n2. Take over the ownership of S3 buckets\\\\n3. Deploy new/additional indexers\\\\n4. Set up indexers monitoring\\\\n5. Set up lake progression monitoring\\\\n6. Set up public status-page\\\\n7. Update all relevant documentation, take over support channels\\\\n8. Make announcements, finish the hand-over\\\\n9. (Optional/Later): integrate lake indexer with existing Aurora infrastructure\\\\n\\\\n## Metrics\\\\n\\\\nKey things that have to be tracked:\\\\n- Per-indexer metrics - have to be exported from indexer instances:\\\\n\\\\t- Liveness status\\\\n\\\\t- Sync/unsync status\\\\n\\\\t- Current progression\\\\n\\\\t- Errors\\\\n- Bucket progression metrics - shall be measured by reading from S3 using lake client library (indexer framework):\\\\n\\\\t- Current progression\\\\n\\\\t- Fetching/parsing errors\\\\n\\\\t- Lag from the final block (shall be compared against final block querying from RPC)\\\\n- Total uptime is calculated as: total time when lag was less than 5 blocks\\\\n\\\\nSuccess condition: uptime during the evaluation period is at least 99.9%\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n\\\\nThe budget might be re-evaluated in future due to:\\\\n\\\\t- Growth of monthly-generated NEAR data\\\\n\\\\t- Pipeline optimizations applied by Aurora Labs team\\\\n\\\\n### Budget total\\\\n\\\\n$35,000 USD per quarter\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\nS3 costs breakdown:\\\\n- Assuming that:\\\\n  - Pricing model is S3 Standard\\\\n    - Storage cost = 0,0245 USD/month/1GB\\\\n    - PUT cost = 0,0054 USD/1000 requests\\\\n    - LIST cost = 0,0054 USD/1000 requests\\\\n    - GET cost = 0,00043 USD/1000 requests\\\\n  - Every block is represented with 7 objects: 1 header + 6 chunks\\\\n  - Every object is written at most 3 times (failover replication)\\\\n    - Note: replication multiplier can be optimized with some effort\\\\n  - Readers are paying for themself\\\\n  - There\\\\u{2019}s 3 progression trackers per network (failover replication) that are reading continuously\\\\n    - Note: replication multiplier can be optimized with some effort\\\\n  - 6TB of data is written every month in average (during 1 year period)\\\\n- Storage cost:\\\\n  - Current storage: 40TB\\\\n  - Storage after 1 year: 40TB + 6TB * 12months = 112TB\\\\n  - Average (during 1 year) monthly storage: (40TB + 112TB) / 2 = 76TB\\\\n  - Average (during 1 year) monthly storage cost: 76TB * 1024 * 0.0245 USD/month/GB = 1907 USD\\\\n  - First year storage cost = 12 * 1907 USD = 22884 USD\\\\n- Blocks per year per network = 365 * 24 * 3600 / 1.2 = 26280000 blocks\\\\n- Objects per year per network = 26280000 blocks * 7 objects = 183960000 objects\\\\n- Write cost:\\\\n  - Writes cost per year per network per instance = 183960000 / 1000 * 0.0054 USD = 993 USD\\\\n  - Total writes cost per year = 1987 USD * 2 networks * 3 replicas = 5958 USD\\\\n- Read cost:\\\\n  - LIST requests per year per network per instance = 183960000 objects / 1000 = 183960 requests\\\\n  - LIST cost per year per network per instance = 183960 / 1000 * 0.0054 USD = 1 USD\\\\n  - GET cost per year per per network instance = 183960000 objects / 1000 * 0.00043 USD = 79 USD\\\\n  - Read cost per year per network per instance = 1 USD + 79 USD = 80 USD\\\\n  - Total read cost per year = 80 USD * 2 networks * 3 replicas = 480 USD\\\\n- Total S3 cost per year = 22884 USD + 5958 USD + 480 USD ~= $30k USD\\\\n\\\\nHardware costs:\\\\n- The optimal fit for one indexer is (for example) Hetzner AX52 with +2+2TB (raid-1) NVME SSD:\\\\n  - Monthly cost: 125 USD\\\\n  - Setup fee: 51 USD\\\\n  - Yearly cost: 51 + 125 * 12 = 1551 USD\\\\n- Total machines needed:\\\\n  - Indexers: 2 networks * 3 replicas = 6\\\\n  - Progression trackers/etc: collocated with other services on different machines, but is equivalent of 1 more machine\\\\n  - 7 machines in total\\\\n- Total cost per year: 7 machines * 1551 USD ~= $11k USD\\\\n\\\\nOperational overhead and safety margin:\\\\n- $8k / month ~= $96k / year\\\\n\\\\nTotal cost for the first year = $30k + $11k + $96k = ~$137k\\\\n\\\\nWe propose to structure the contract with quarterly payments: $35k/quarter\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "aurorasupport.near", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "35000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDC"}, "labels": []}

{"body": {"name": "NEAR Lake, Public Datasets and KitWallet Proposal by former Pagoda Data Team", "summary": "Two core developers on the Data Platform team propose to take over NEAR Lake, Public Datasets powering analytics, and KitWallet, on a 2-year contract. RFPs: [NEAR Lake](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=3), [BigQuery and Data Pipelines](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=4) and [KitWallet](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=1). ", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "DRAFT"}, "linked_rfp": 3, "description": "\\\\n\\\\n# Organization\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\u{2019}s contact information\\\\n\\\\nPavel Kudinov \\\\u{2013} pavel@blocklake.io; Telegram @paulksg\\\\nWebsite: [https://www.blocklake.io/](https://www.blocklake.io/)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n\\\\nCurrently two people\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### The size of the engineering team\\\\n\\\\nCurrently two people \\\\u{2013} Pavel Kudinov and Eduardo Ohe. We plan to engage DevOps/SRE on a contract when necessary.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Team location\\\\n\\\\nVancouver, Canada\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Team background and bios\\\\n\\\\nFor the past ~2 years, we both have been the senior-most members of the Pagoda Data Team, working on NEAR Lake, Databricks Lakehouse powering NEAR Foundation analytics, BigQuery and Dune integration, as well as optimizing the performance of critical databases of EnhancedAPI, Explorer, and QueryAPI.\\\\n\\\\n**Eduardo Ohe** \\\\u{2013} Currently a staff engineer at the Pagoda team running data infra, including hands-on work on NEAR Lake, Databricks, Public Datasets/BigQuery/Dune integrations, and KitWallet. He shared and advocated for NEAR data solutions in the [Google tech blogs](https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/partners/increasing-blockchain-accessibility-for-devops) and in the last [Databricks DATA+AI Summit](https://www.databricks.com/dataaisummit/session/sponsored-google-scale-your-databricks-workloads-15k-nodes-google-cloud) as a co-speaker. Over 28 years of experience with software engineering and big data, he has an MBA and a Bachelor of Computer Science that helped him to make bridges between business needs and tech solutions. He has experience as a CTO | Co-founder running his own BI/CRM company with +30 employees and successful exit. He also led data engineering projects for [petabyte-scale datasets at Twitter](https://blog.x.com/engineering/en_us/topics/infrastructure/2022/scaling-data-access-by-moving-an-exabyte-of-data-to-google-cloud) ensuring its [data quality/reliability.](https://blog.x.com/engineering/en_us/topics/infrastructure/2022/data-quality-automation-at-twitter) \\\\n\\\\n**Pavel Kudinov** \\\\u{2013} Currently a senior manager at the Pagoda team running data infra, including NEAR Lake. Over 18 years of experience in building Data Science products. More than 5 years serving in Director of Engineering or CTO-like roles, experience running private data consulting and creating startups from scratch.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Examples of relevant experience with NEAR blockchain\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* NEAR Lake Primitives library, simplifying data extraction from NEAR Lake JSON files: [https://github.com/near/near-lake-framework-js/tree/main/packages/near-lake-primitives](https://github.com/near/near-lake-framework-js/tree/main/packages/near-lake-primitives) \\\\n* Databricks Lakehouse, powered by NEAR Lake: [https://github.com/near/near-public-lakehouse](https://github.com/near/near-public-lakehouse)\\\\n* BigQuery integration: [https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?p=bigquery-public-data&d=crypto_near_mainnet_us&page=dataset](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?p=bigquery-public-data&d=crypto_near_mainnet_us&page=dataset)\\\\n* NEAR QueryAPI, powered by NEAR Lake: [https://github.com/near/queryapi](https://github.com/near/queryapi)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Non-technical capabilities:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Leadership.** Pavel has experience building and running product, data, and software engineering since 2008.\\\\n* **Data Consulting.** Both Eduardo and Pavel have experience running data consulting (data engineering and business intelligence) for small and big businesses in Brazil and Singapore.\\\\n* **Business Development**. we have experience working with B2B clients and establishing partnerships.\\\\n* **Project Management**. Pavel has experience running large-scale, multi-quarter projects across multiple teams involving data-intensive applications with high SLAs.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### In-House Resources;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* Design, UX/UI\\\\n * For this RFP, we don\\\\u{2019}t need Design or UX work. However, we have preliminary agreements with existing Pagoda designers to help with design work if necessary.\\\\n* Project management\\\\n * Pavel Kudinov will be handling project management\\\\n* Customer support\\\\n * Eduardo and Pavel will share handling customer support. Based on our experience so far, there are not many daily requests.\\\\n* BD / Marketing\\\\n * Pavel and Eduardo have experience with BD and partnership management from our consulting experience. For Marketing, we will rely on external partners known in the NEAR ecosystem when required.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Portfolio of relevant work\\\\n\\\\nFor this RFP, the most relevant is that we had been working with NEAR Lake for 2 years and significantly contributed to many tools running on top of it.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Body\\\\n\\\\nBlockLake Inc will be focusing on the following:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* raw blockchain data extraction, hosting, and serving;\\\\n* building data pipelines for analytics, powering Near Foundation, Dune and BigQuery;\\\\n* critical APIs for most popular and essential use cases, such as native and FT token balance history;\\\\n* consulting services for external clients;\\\\n* In the future, multichain indexing and APIs.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### The main approach and solution of the proposal\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n1. Take over existing infrastructure for NEAR Lake: hosting NEAR Indexer nodes and the S3 bucket.\\\\n2. Utilize our expertise to build better and even cheaper access tools for people using NEAR Lake and offering it based on subscription:\\\\n 1. Block index to query only relevant blocks\\\\n 2. Block and transaction streaming through WebSockets and/or Webhooks\\\\n3. Take over critical data pipelines for integrating Dune (and maintaining ~$350k annual savings) and BigQuery.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Why should the committee choose this project?\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n1. The team behind this proposal has profound knowledge of the domain and technical architecture. Zero migration and onboarding costs.\\\\n2. Internal and External users rely on the high-quality datasets that we already built; other data sources are not as reliable. Data Analytics and AI use cases require high-quality data.\\\\n3. Dune\\\\u{2019}s proposal cost was reduced by 50% only because we did most of the work on the NEAR Lakehouse.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Will this solution be open source? What licensing will be used?\\\\n\\\\nWe will keep the same open source license that NEAR GitHub repos have currently for all public goods code \\\\u{2013} the NEAR Lake, client libraries and data pipelines.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* By February 2025\\\\n * Incorporate the company, establish operations\\\\n * Takeover existing Lake infrastructure as is with existing costs, ensuring non-disruptive transition of all existing clients\\\\n * Replace Databricks with the cheaper alternative to empower Dune and BigQuery use-cases\\\\n* By July 2025\\\\n * First revenue from consulting services and custom indexers\\\\n * First revenue from NEAR Streams \\\\u{2013} a cheaper way to stream transactions to clients, reducing network costs and latency.\\\\n * Reduction of infrastructure costs to run NEAR Lake (using dedicated servers)\\\\n* By December 2025\\\\n * Expand the Lake for another blockchain(s)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Service Level Agreements \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Support\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Support Availability**: Community-based support only (e.g., through forums, GitHub issues, or a developer community Slack/Telegram/Discord channel)\\\\n* **Response Time**: No guaranteed response time, but best-effort responses within 24-48 hours\\\\n* **No SLA Credits**: No financial credits or compensation for outages or performance issues to the users.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Legal\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Terms & Conditions:** We will provide a clear T&C and Privacy Policy facilitating fair usage of services, following best practices.\\\\n* **Fair Use Policy**: Explicit statements about the intended use for development and the prohibition of production workloads\\\\n* **Termination Rights**: The right to suspend or terminate the service for users who exceed fair use or misuse the service. IC must be informed about these.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Technical\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Availability**\\\\n * **Uptime Guarantee**: 99.0% for Lake and 95% for Public Datasets monthly uptime \\\\n * **Downtime Allowance**: Up to 1% for Lake and 5% for Public Datasets of downtime per month\\\\n* **Performance**\\\\n* **Data freshness**:\\\\n * NEAR Lake: 99% monthly SLA that the Lake is less than 5 blocks from the latest finalized block.\\\\n * Public Datasets: 99% monthly SLA that all datasets are within 1 hour from the tip of the network.\\\\n* **Rate Limiting**:\\\\n * As defined in the rate limit plan with gradual reductions for both Lake and public datasets\\\\n* **Rate Limit Enforcement**: Strict enforcement with immediate rate limit application once thresholds are reached for both Lake and public datasets\\\\n* **Updates and Changes**\\\\n* **Notice for Breaking Changes**: At least 7 days\\\\\\' notice for any breaking changes in the Lake services or infrastructure\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Usage & Examples\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* NEAR Lake is critical for the Ecosystem\\\\n * NEAR Lake has 75 active users with ~103 blocks/second served on average\\\\n * 2 Billion HTTP requests served monthly\\\\n* Public Dataset is critical for the Ecosystem\\\\n * BigQuery is used by Nansen, SWEAT, NEAR NDC and others\\\\n * Allows to save ~$350K on Dune integration annually\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Budget\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Total\\\\n\\\\nWe ask for a budget for 2 years, with possible extension further upon review. The budget includes infrastructure growth costs, as we expect to put engineering effort to reduce them.\\\\n\\\\nProposed: **$327,500** / quarter\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Quarterly Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n

We plan to engage DevOps/SRE on a contract when necessary.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Team location\\\\n\\\\nVancouver, Canada\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Team background and bios\\\\n\\\\nFor the past ~2 years, we both have been the senior-most members of the Pagoda Data Team, working on NEAR Lake, Databricks Lakehouse powering NEAR Foundation analytics, BigQuery and Dune integration, as well as optimizing the performance of critical databases of EnhancedAPI, Explorer, and QueryAPI.\\\\n\\\\n**Eduardo Ohe** \\\\u{2013} Currently a staff engineer at the Pagoda team running data infra, including hands-on work on NEAR Lake, Databricks, Public Datasets/BigQuery/Dune integrations, and KitWallet. He shared and advocated for NEAR data solutions in the [Google tech blogs](https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/partners/increasing-blockchain-accessibility-for-devops) and in the last [Databricks DATA+AI Summit](https://www.databricks.com/dataaisummit/session/sponsored-google-scale-your-databricks-workloads-15k-nodes-google-cloud) as a co-speaker. Over 28 years of experience with software engineering and big data, he has an MBA and a Bachelor of Computer Science that helped him to make bridges between business needs and tech solutions. He has experience as a CTO | Co-founder running his own BI/CRM company with +30 employees and successful exit. He also led data engineering projects for [petabyte-scale datasets at Twitter](https://blog.x.com/engineering/en_us/topics/infrastructure/2022/scaling-data-access-by-moving-an-exabyte-of-data-to-google-cloud) ensuring its [data quality/reliability.](https://blog.x.com/engineering/en_us/topics/infrastructure/2022/data-quality-automation-at-twitter) \\\\n\\\\n**Pavel Kudinov** \\\\u{2013} Currently a senior manager at the Pagoda team running data infra, including NEAR Lake. Over 18 years of experience in building Data Science products. Pavel has experience running large-scale, multi-quarter projects across multiple teams involving data-intensive applications with high SLAs.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### In-House Resources;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* Design, UX/UI\\\\n * For this RFP, we don\\\\u{2019}t need Design or UX work. However, we have preliminary agreements with existing Pagoda designers to help with design work if necessary.\\\\n* Project management\\\\n * Pavel Kudinov will be handling project management\\\\n* Customer support\\\\n * Eduardo and Pavel will share handling customer support. Based on our experience so far, there are not many daily requests.\\\\n* BD / Marketing\\\\n * Pavel and Eduardo have experience with BD and partnership management from our consulting experience. For Marketing, we will rely on external partners known in the NEAR ecosystem when required.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Portfolio of relevant work\\\\n\\\\nFor this RFP, the most relevant is that we had been working with NEAR Lake for 2 years and significantly contributed to many tools running on top of it.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Body\\\\n\\\\nBlockLake Inc will be focusing on the following:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* raw blockchain data extraction, hosting, and serving;\\\\n* building data pipelines for analytics, powering Near Foundation, Dune and BigQuery;\\\\n* critical APIs for most popular and essential use cases, such as native and FT token balance history;\\\\n* consulting services for external clients;\\\\n* In the future, multichain indexing and APIs.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### The main approach and solution of the proposal\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n1. Take over existing infrastructure for NEAR Lake: hosting NEAR Indexer nodes and the S3 bucket.\\\\n2. Utilize our expertise to build better and even cheaper access tools for people using NEAR Lake and offering it based on subscription:\\\\n 1. Block index to query only relevant blocks\\\\n 2. Block and transaction streaming through WebSockets and/or Webhooks\\\\n3. Take over critical data pipelines for integrating Dune (and maintaining ~$350k annual savings) and BigQuery.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Why should the committee choose this project?\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n1. The team behind this proposal has profound knowledge of the domain and technical architecture. Zero migration and onboarding costs.\\\\n2. Internal and External users rely on the high-quality datasets that we already built; other data sources are not as reliable. Data Analytics and AI use cases require high-quality data.\\\\n3. IC must be informed about these.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Technical\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Availability**\\\\n * **Uptime Guarantee**: 99.0% for Lake and 95% for Public Datasets monthly uptime \\\\n * **Downtime Allowance**: Up to 1% for Lake and 5% for Public Datasets of downtime per month\\\\n* **Performance**\\\\n* **Data freshness**:\\\\n * NEAR Lake: 99% monthly SLA that the Lake is less than 5 blocks from the latest finalized block.\\\\n * Public Datasets: 99% monthly SLA that all datasets are within 1 hour from the tip of the network.\\\\n* **Rate Limiting**:\\\\n * As defined in the rate limit plan with gradual reductions for both Lake and public datasets\\\\n* **Rate Limit Enforcement**: Strict enforcement with immediate rate limit application once thresholds are reached for both Lake and public datasets\\\\n* **Updates and Changes**\\\\n* **Notice for Breaking Changes**: At least 7 days\\\\\\' notice for any breaking changes in the Lake services or infrastructure\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Usage & Examples\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* NEAR Lake is critical for the Ecosystem\\\\n * NEAR Lake has 75 active users with ~103 blocks/second served on average\\\\n * 2 Billion HTTP requests served monthly\\\\n* Public Dataset is critical for the Ecosystem\\\\n * BigQuery is used by Nansen, SWEAT, NEAR NDC and others\\\\n * Allows to save ~$350K on Dune integration annually\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Budget\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Total\\\\n\\\\nWe ask for a budget for 2 years, with possible extension further upon review. The budget includes infrastructure growth costs, as we expect to put engineering effort to reduce them.\\\\n\\\\nProposed: **$327,500** / quarter\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Quarterly Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n

{"id": 37, "body": {"name": "NEAR Lake, Public Datasets and KitWallet Proposal by former Pagoda Data Team", "summary": "Two core developers on the Data Platform team propose to take over NEAR Lake, Public Datasets powering analytics, and KitWallet, on a 2-year contract. ", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "DRAFT"}, "linked_rfp": 3, "supervisor": null, "description": "\\\\nThis is a combined proposal for the following RFPs: [NEAR Lake](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=3), [BigQuery and Data Pipelines](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=4) and [KitWallet](https://dev.near.org/infrastructure-committee.near/widget/app?page=rfp&id=1). \\\\n# Organization\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\u{2019}s contact information\\\\n\\\\nPavel Kudinov \\\\u{2013} pavel@blocklake.io; Telegram @paulksg\\\\nWebsite: [https://www.blocklake.io/](https://www.blocklake.io/)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n\\\\nCurrently two people\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### The size of the engineering team\\\\n\\\\nCurrently two people \\\\u{2013} Pavel Kudinov and Eduardo Ohe. We plan to engage DevOps/SRE on a contract when necessary.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Team location\\\\n\\\\nVancouver, Canada\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Team background and bios\\\\n\\\\nFor the past ~2 years, we both have been the senior-most members of the Pagoda Data Team, working on NEAR Lake, Databricks Lakehouse powering NEAR Foundation analytics, BigQuery and Dune integration, as well as optimizing the performance of critical databases of EnhancedAPI, Explorer, and QueryAPI.\\\\n\\\\n**Eduardo Ohe** \\\\u{2013} Currently a staff engineer at the Pagoda team running data infra, including hands-on work on NEAR Lake, Databricks, Public Datasets/BigQuery/Dune integrations, and KitWallet. He shared and advocated for NEAR data solutions in the [Google tech blogs](https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/partners/increasing-blockchain-accessibility-for-devops) and in the last [Databricks DATA+AI Summit](https://www.databricks.com/dataaisummit/session/sponsored-google-scale-your-databricks-workloads-15k-nodes-google-cloud) as a co-speaker. Over 28 years of experience with software engineering and big data, he has an MBA and a Bachelor of Computer Science that helped him to make bridges between business needs and tech solutions. He has experience as a CTO | Co-founder running his own BI/CRM company with +30 employees and successful exit. He also led data engineering projects for [petabyte-scale datasets at Twitter](https://blog.x.com/engineering/en_us/topics/infrastructure/2022/scaling-data-access-by-moving-an-exabyte-of-data-to-google-cloud) ensuring its [data quality/reliability.](https://blog.x.com/engineering/en_us/topics/infrastructure/2022/data-quality-automation-at-twitter) \\\\n\\\\n**Pavel Kudinov** \\\\u{2013} Currently a senior manager at the Pagoda team running data infra, including NEAR Lake. Over 18 years of experience in building Data Science products. More than 5 years serving in Director of Engineering or CTO-like roles, experience running private data consulting and creating startups from scratch.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Examples of relevant experience with NEAR blockchain\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* NEAR Lake Primitives library, simplifying data extraction from NEAR Lake JSON files: [https://github.com/near/near-lake-framework-js/tree/main/packages/near-lake-primitives](https://github.com/near/near-lake-framework-js/tree/main/packages/near-lake-primitives) \\\\n* Databricks Lakehouse, powered by NEAR Lake: [https://github.com/near/near-public-lakehouse](https://github.com/near/near-public-lakehouse)\\\\n* BigQuery integration: [https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?p=bigquery-public-data&d=crypto_near_mainnet_us&page=dataset](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?p=bigquery-public-data&d=crypto_near_mainnet_us&page=dataset)\\\\n* NEAR QueryAPI, powered by NEAR Lake: [https://github.com/near/queryapi](https://github.com/near/queryapi)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Non-technical capabilities:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Leadership.** Pavel has experience building and running product, data, and software engineering since 2008.\\\\n* **Data Consulting.** Both Eduardo and Pavel have experience running data consulting (data engineering and business intelligence) for small and big businesses in Brazil and Singapore.\\\\n* **Business Development**. we have experience working with B2B clients and establishing partnerships.\\\\n* **Project Management**. Pavel has experience running large-scale, multi-quarter projects across multiple teams involving data-intensive applications with high SLAs.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### In-House Resources;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* Design, UX/UI\\\\n * For this RFP, we don\\\\u{2019}t need Design or UX work. However, we have preliminary agreements with existing Pagoda designers to help with design work if necessary.\\\\n* Project management\\\\n * Pavel Kudinov will be handling project management\\\\n* Customer support\\\\n * Eduardo and Pavel will share handling customer support. Based on our experience so far, there are not many daily requests.\\\\n* BD / Marketing\\\\n * Pavel and Eduardo have experience with BD and partnership management from our consulting experience. For Marketing, we will rely on external partners known in the NEAR ecosystem when required.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Portfolio of relevant work\\\\n\\\\nFor this RFP, the most relevant is that we had been working with NEAR Lake for 2 years and significantly contributed to many tools running on top of it.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Body\\\\n\\\\nBlockLake Inc will be focusing on the following:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* raw blockchain data extraction, hosting, and serving;\\\\n* building data pipelines for analytics, powering Near Foundation, Dune and BigQuery;\\\\n* critical APIs for most popular and essential use cases, such as native and FT token balance history;\\\\n* consulting services for external clients;\\\\n* In the future, multichain indexing and APIs.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### The main approach and solution of the proposal\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n1. Take over existing infrastructure for NEAR Lake: hosting NEAR Indexer nodes and the S3 bucket.\\\\n2. Utilize our expertise to build better and even cheaper access tools for people using NEAR Lake and offering it based on subscription:\\\\n 1. Block index to query only relevant blocks\\\\n 2. Block and transaction streaming through WebSockets and/or Webhooks\\\\n3. Take over critical data pipelines for integrating Dune (and maintaining ~$350k annual savings) and BigQuery.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Why should the committee choose this project?\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n1. The team behind this proposal has profound knowledge of the domain and technical architecture. Zero migration and onboarding costs.\\\\n2. Internal and External users rely on the high-quality datasets that we already built; other data sources are not as reliable. Data Analytics and AI use cases require high-quality data.\\\\n3. Dune\\\\u{2019}s proposal cost was reduced by 50% only because we did most of the work on the NEAR Lakehouse.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Will this solution be open source? What licensing will be used?\\\\n\\\\nWe will keep the same open source license that NEAR GitHub repos have currently for all public goods code \\\\u{2013} the NEAR Lake, client libraries and data pipelines.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* By February 2025\\\\n * Incorporate the company, establish operations\\\\n * Takeover existing Lake infrastructure as is with existing costs, ensuring non-disruptive transition of all existing clients\\\\n * Replace Databricks with the cheaper alternative to empower Dune and BigQuery use-cases\\\\n* By July 2025\\\\n * First revenue from consulting services and custom indexers\\\\n * First revenue from NEAR Streams \\\\u{2013} a cheaper way to stream transactions to clients, reducing network costs and latency.\\\\n * Reduction of infrastructure costs to run NEAR Lake (using dedicated servers)\\\\n* By December 2025\\\\n * Expand the Lake for another blockchain(s)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Service Level Agreements \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Support\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Support Availability**: Community-based support only (e.g., through forums, GitHub issues, or a developer community Slack/Telegram/Discord channel)\\\\n* **Response Time**: No guaranteed response time, but best-effort responses within 24-48 hours\\\\n* **No SLA Credits**: No financial credits or compensation for outages or performance issues to the users.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Legal\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Terms & Conditions:** We will provide a clear T&C and Privacy Policy facilitating fair usage of services, following best practices.\\\\n* **Fair Use Policy**: Explicit statements about the intended use for development and the prohibition of production workloads\\\\n* **Termination Rights**: The right to suspend or terminate the service for users who exceed fair use or misuse the service. IC must be informed about these.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Technical\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* **Availability**\\\\n * **Uptime Guarantee**: 99.0% for Lake and 95% for Public Datasets monthly uptime \\\\n * **Downtime Allowance**: Up to 1% for Lake and 5% for Public Datasets of downtime per month\\\\n* **Data freshness**:\\\\n * NEAR Lake: 99% monthly SLA that the Lake is less than 5 blocks from the latest finalized block.\\\\n * Public Datasets: 99% monthly SLA that all datasets are within 1 hour from the tip of the network.\\\\n* **Rate Limiting**:\\\\n * As defined in the rate limit plan with gradual reductions for both Lake and public datasets\\\\n* **Rate Limit Enforcement**: Strict enforcement with immediate rate limit application once thresholds are reached for both Lake and public datasets\\\\n* **Updates and Changes**\\\\n* **Notice for Breaking Changes**: At least 7 days\\\\\\' notice for any breaking changes in the Lake services or infrastructure\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Usage & Examples\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n* NEAR Lake is critical for the Ecosystem\\\\n * NEAR Lake has 75 active users with ~103 blocks/second served on average\\\\n * 2 Billion HTTP requests served monthly\\\\n* Public Dataset is critical for the Ecosystem\\\\n * BigQuery is used by Nansen, SWEAT, NEAR NDC and others\\\\n * Allows to save ~$350K on Dune integration annually\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n# Budget\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Total\\\\n\\\\nWe ask for a budget for 2 years, with possible extension further upon review. The budget includes infrastructure growth costs, as we expect to put engineering effort to reduce them.\\\\n\\\\nProposed: **$327,500** / quarter\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n### Quarterly Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n \\\\n

{"body": {"name": "near.org RPC service by FASTNEAR", "summary": "Provide near.org RPC service by FASTNEAR", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "DRAFT"}, "linked_rfp": 2, "supervisor": null, "description": "# near.org RPC service by FASTNEAR\\\\n\\\\n## Organization\\\\n\\\\nFASTNEAR\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\\\'s contact information\\\\nEvgeny Kuzyakov (ek@fastnear.com)\\\\n\\\\n### About\\\\n\\\\n[FASTNEAR](https://fastnear.com) is NEAR Protocol Infrastructure Provider.\\\\n\\\\n#### [Services](https://fastnear.com/services)\\\\n- RPC endpoints\\\\n- API for wallets\\\\n- Snapshot data\\\\n- Indexing and Lake solutions\\\\n- Validator services\\\\n\\\\n#### Key Features\\\\n1. **Dedicated to NEAR Protocol:** We exclusively serve the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n2. **High-Performance Infrastructure:** \\\\n   - The majority of nodes and servers hosted on bare-metal.\\\\n   - Currently ~4,000 RPC requests per second. Resulting in 320M calls per day.\\\\n\\\\n#### Reliability and Security\\\\n- Experienced in handling:\\\\n  - Traffic surges of 30,000 RPS\\\\n  - DDoS attacks (recently)\\\\n  - Provider outages\\\\n- ~100% RPCs uptime for the last 3 months\\\\n- 250ms p95 over 60min view call latency\\\\n\\\\n#### Monitoring and Performance\\\\n- Internal monitoring and alert systems\\\\n- Global RPC latency monitoring dashboards\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\n\\\\n### Hardware\\\\n\\\\nBased on the current usage of the following:\\\\n- RPC Mainnet - 10k requests/s (while currently 6k RPS)\\\\n- RPC-Archival Mainnet - 2k requests/s\\\\n- RPC Testnet - 400 requests/s\\\\n- RPC-Archival Testnet - 150 requests/s\\\\n\\\\nWe recommend the following setup:\\\\n- RPC Mainnet: 20 nodes (estimating 500 RPS each)\\\\n- RPC-Archival Mainnet: 4 full NVME nodes, with 10Gbps (at 500 RPS)\\\\n- RPC Testnet - 4 nodes (for 2X redundancy)\\\\n- RPC-Archival Testnet - 2 full NVME nodes (for 2X redundancy)\\\\n\\\\nNote, that we don\\\\\\'t rely on the read-rpc for this setup, due to the current setup complexity. We may consider switching to read-rpc over time.\\\\n\\\\n**Pricing**\\\\n\\\\nThree types of servers:\\\\n- RPC (mainnet/testnet): $250 with 2Tb NVME + 1Gbps\\\\n- RPC-Archive Mainnet: $2500 with 90Tb NVME + ~250TB of 10Gpbs traffic\\\\n- RPC-Archive Testnet: $1000 with ~20Tb NVME + 1Gbps\\\\n\\\\nTotal:\\\\n- 24 RPC nodes: $6000\\\\n- 4 Mainnet Archival nodes: $10000\\\\n- 2 Testnet Archival nodes: $2000\\\\n\\\\n**Total: $18000 per month**\\\\n\\\\n### Load-balancing\\\\n\\\\nOur current RPC setup is using a simple DNS-based load balancer. This works well for front-end clients which come from the different IPs. This setup has quite low cost overhead, but it can\\\\\\'t be used to minimize GEO-spatial latency. There is a latency overhead, because each request might be routed not to the closest server, but instead to a server on a different continent. While it does increase latency by up to ~140ms, we don\\\\\\'t consider it significant enough to justify costs associated with geo-spatial load-balancing.\\\\n\\\\n#### Expected load\\\\n\\\\n- ~12500 RPS\\\\n- 32.4B requests per month\\\\n- 93TB per month\\\\n\\\\nMost load balancer providers have costs associated with the number of requests. While GCP doesn\\\\\\'t charge for the number of requests, it has limitations of load balancing across external endpoints and does charge for the traffic.\\\\n\\\\n*Note, we don\\\\\\'t have enough experience with GCP load-balancing, so some assumptions might be wrong.*\\\\n\\\\nWe have considered the following options for this proposal:\\\\n1. Simple DNS-based load-balancing\\\\n3. **PREFERRED** Cloudflare Enterprise geo-spatial load-balancing.\\\\n4. Google Cloud Provider Load Balancing with proxy instances or GCP LB with simple traffic splitting.\\\\n\\\\n#### Option #1: Simple DNS-based load-balancing\\\\n\\\\nWe can use a CNAME record for each of the near.org endpoints to point to our endpoints(s).\\\\n\\\\nThis option might be fairly simple to setup at **no extra cost**.\\\\n\\\\nNote, Strict rate-limiting on HTTP referer will require extra work on nodes or an enterprise plan.\\\\n\\\\n#### Option #2: Cloudflare Enterprise Load-balancing (CF LB)\\\\n\\\\nSimple DNS-based load-balancing can be upgraded to geo-spatial load-balancing at our end.\\\\n\\\\nDuring the communication with Cloudflare sales, we\\\\\\'ve received an estimate for 15B requests per month. Scaling it up to 32.4B requests, the price might be around **~$6000 per month**.\\\\n\\\\nCloudflare enterprise offers rate limiting based on HTTP headers, including HTTP Referer or HTTP Origin.\\\\n\\\\n#### Option #3: Google Cloud Provider Load Balancing (GCP LB)\\\\n\\\\nGCP external load balancer has bandwidth associated with it. \\\\nBased on our estimates, the LB traffic is around $10 per TB for ingress, and $10 per TB for egress.\\\\n\\\\nGCP LB can\\\\\\'t be used for geo-spatial balancing without additional nodes on GCP or other cloud run/functions.\\\\n\\\\nSo there are 2 options for GCP:\\\\n- Full load-balancing. Requires RPC egress traffic with proxy nodes. Costs *estimated* **~$16000 per month**\\\\n- Splitting traffic (no geo-spatial routing). Costs around **~$2000 month**. Need to confirm feasibility.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n- Setup (2 weeks)\\\\n    - Setup RPC nodes and Archival RPC nodes\\\\n    - Setup 4 endpoints to point traffic\\\\n    - Rate-limiters based on IPs\\\\n- Status page for new endpoints (2 weeks)\\\\n- Setup external monitoring dashboard (4 weeks)\\\\n- Setup CF LB (4-8 weeks)\\\\n    - Negotiate deal with CF for LB\\\\n    - Setup rate limiter based on the HTTP referer.\\\\n- Full endpoints migration if necessary (3-6 months)\\\\n\\\\n## Metrics\\\\n\\\\n- Requests per second\\\\n    - All request types (expected to handle steady traffic of 12,500 RPS)\\\\n    - Function calls (majority of requests)\\\\n    - TX status\\\\n    - Broadcast TX\\\\n- Latency\\\\n    - Mean latency from 3 geo endpoints (~170ms for view calls)\\\\n    - P95 latency (~250ms for calls)\\\\n    - Lower mean/p95 latency after CF LB\\\\n- Rate limiting (number of throttled calls)\\\\n- Traffic (expected up to 3Tb per day)\\\\n- Uptime (expected 99.99%)\\\\n\\\\n### Compensation\\\\n\\\\nFor maintenance and development we ask for $12,000 a month.\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n\\\\n$36,000 per month (paid monthly) for the duration of 6 months.\\\\n- $18,000 nodes\\\\n- $6,000 CF LB\\\\n- $12,000 maintenance \\\\n\\\\nAfter 6 months, we expect a significant drop in the usage, so we should re-negotiate a deal based on the new requirements.\\\\n\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "treasury.fastnear.tg", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "216000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDC"}, "labels": []}

{"id": 1, "body": {"name": "Kit Wallet Indexer API", "summary": "Kit Wallet Indexer API is an undocumented but widely used lightweight indexer that helps to find user\\\\u{2019}s FTs, NFTs, and accounts by public key, that builds off of [NEAR Lake Framework](https://docs.near.org/concepts/advanced/near-lake-framework) (which also has an RFP). As [Pagoda winds down its services](https://docs.near.org/blog/2024-08-13-pagoda-services), there is a need to transition the management and development of the Kit Wallet Indexer to a capable service provider.", "timeline": {"status": "ACCEPTING_SUBMISSIONS"}, "description": "## Overview\\\\n\\\\nKit Wallet Indexer API is an undocumented but widely used lightweight indexer that helps to find user\\\\u{2019}s FTs, NFTs, and accounts by public key, that builds off of [NEAR Lake Framework](https://docs.near.org/concepts/advanced/near-lake-framework) (which also has an RFP). As [Pagoda winds down its services](https://docs.near.org/blog/2024-08-13-pagoda-services), there is a need to transition the management and development of the Kit Wallet Indexer to a capable service provider. The transition aims to ensure uninterrupted service of this vital data infrastructure, which is essential for various stakeholders in the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\n* Indexer Endpoints API: [https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/indexer.js](https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/indexer.js)\\\\n* Indexer Endpoints Code: [https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js](https://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js)\\\\n\\\\n**Current live endpoints**\\\\n\\\\n* Mainnet [https://api.kitwallet.app/](https://api.kitwallet.app/) (currently hosted on AWS)\\\\n* Testnet [https://testnet-api.kitwallet.app/](https://testnet-api.kitwallet.app/)\\\\n\\\\n## Requirements\\\\n\\\\n**Include the following endpoints on mainnet and testnet:**\\\\n\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/publicKey/:publicKey/accounts\\\\\\', findAccountsByPublicKey);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/staking-deposits/:accountId\\\\\\', findStakingDeposits);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/activity\\\\\\', findAccountActivity);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/callReceivers\\\\\\', findReceivers);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyTokens\\\\\\', findLikelyTokens);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyNFTs\\\\\\', findLikelyNFTs);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyTokensFromBlock\\\\\\', findLikelyTokensFromBlock);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/account/:accountId/likelyNFTsFromBlock\\\\\\', findLikelyNFTsFromBlock);\\\\n* router.get(\\\\\\'/stakingPools\\\\\\', findStakingPools);\\\\n\\\\n**An instance of PostgresSQL, copy of databases, and implemented as follows:**\\\\nhttps://github.com/near/near-contract-helper/blob/master/src/middleware/indexer.js#L11\\\\n\\\\nYou are free to change out this requirement with another implementation of your choice.\\\\n\\\\n## Usage \\\\n\\\\nThe graph below indicates the most recent usage for the past months KitWallet LB requests: ~350K per day (average response time is less than 0.14 seconds, but there are spikes of 50 seconds or more currently)\\\\n\\\\n![alt_text](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a5b10c0a-7aba-4d44-bd33-7a5ae05e42e1 \\\\\\\"image_tooltip\\\\\\\")\\\\n\\\\n![alt_text](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7c4fc10a-8b12-48be-be65-c1b01336b7d5 \\\\\\\"image_tooltip\\\\\\\")\\\\n\\\\n_Note: the majority of endpoint usage, [FastNear](https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs) already supports_\\\\n\\\\nThis Kit Wallet Indexer API is undocumented and not officially supported.  Because of this, many wallets that are more NEAR \\\\u{201c}native\\\\u{201d} have already switched to other solutions like [FastNEAR](https://github.com/fastnear/fastnear-api-server-rs).
